WCAG stands for "Web Compliance and Accessibility Guidelines"

For a website to meet WCAG 2.1 AA it must meet both Level A and Level AA Criteria
The WCAG guidelines are legally required by all countries
Text that cannot be resized without assistive technology fails WCAG Level AA compliance
Providing captions for live audio content is required to meet WCAG Level A
WCAG 2.1 includes guidelines for both visual and auditory disabilities
Web accessibility only applies to people with visual impairments
Keyboard navigation is an important part of making a website accessible
Accessible websites should avoid using flash content that could trigger seizures
Alternative text for images is not required if the image is decorative
ARIA (Accessible Rich Internet Applications) is a set of attributes that help make dynamic content more accessible
Websites should not have any keyboard traps which means users cannot be trapped in a section using the keyboard.
A skip navigation link is unnecessary if your website is accessible
Descriptive headings and labels can enhance web accessibility
Large font sizes can substitute for contrast in making text accessible
Ensuring that all form elements have associated labels is important for web accessibility
It is acceptable for links to be identified solely by color
PDFs can be made accessible by adding proper tags and structure
Testing your website with only one screen reader is enough to confirm accessibility
Plain language is important for improving web accessibility for people with cognitive disabilities.
A website’s color scheme has no impact on web accessibility
Transcripts are required for prerecorded audio-only content to meet WCAG Level AA
HTML5 has built-in accessibility features that help make websites more accessible
The tab order of a web page is irrelevant for accessibility.
Keyboard users should be able to activate all website functionality including interactive elements.
Access keys are recommended for improving web accessibility.
HTML <table> elements should always include <caption> tags to describe the table’s purpose.
An empty alt attribute (alt="") should be used for purely decorative images.
The <label> element should always be associated with form controls like input fields
HTML5 semantic elements like <header> <footer> and <article> help improve accessibility.
The <iframe> element does not need a title attribute for accessibility.
Using <strong> and <em> tags instead of <b> and <i> improves accessibility for screen readers.
It is best practice to avoid using the tabindex attribute unless necessary.
Heading tags (<h1> <h2> etc.) should always be used in a logical order to ensure accessibility
HTML <input> elements for forms can be left without any type attributes.
The ARIA role "alert" is used to display urgent messages to assistive technologies.
It is acceptable to use only ARIA roles and ignore native HTML semantics.
The lang attribute on the <html> tag is important for accessibility.
If a button only contains an icon (with no text) it should still have an accessible label.
HTML headings should be styled visually without considering their semantic importance
Using ARIA to label interactive elements is more effective than using native HTML labels.
Anchor tags (<a>) without href attributes are accessible and usable.
The <alt> attribute for images should be descriptive enough for users who cannot see the image.
The title attribute is always a suitable replacement for the aria-label attribute on elements.
WAI-ARIA roles and properties should only be used when native HTML does not suffice.
